subject: GRAD
title: Prep Univ Tchg NN Eng Spkrs
info: Theory/practice of teaching in higher education in the United States. Emphasizes clear oral classroom communication and development of presentation skills. Students practice in a simulated instructional setting.
prereqInfo: prereq: English Language Proficiency Rating of 4; Contact cei@umn.edu for permission number.

subject: GRAD
title: Prac Univ Tchg NN Spkrs
info: Theory, advanced practice in teaching in higher education for nonnative speakers of English. Emphasizes interactive teaching strategies, awareness of cross-cultural classroom issues,oral classroom presentation skills, and legal/policy issues.
prereqInfo: prereq: 5102 or English Language Proficiency Rating of 2; Contact cei@umn.edu for permission number.

subject: GRAD
title: Teaching in Higher Education
info: Teaching methods/techniques. Active learning, critical thinking, practice teaching, and preparing a portfolio to document/reflect upon teaching. Readings, discussion, peer teaching, e-mail dialog, reflective writing, co-facilitation of course.
prereqInfo: prereq: Non-Degree Students: contact pffcollege consentumn.edu with questions about registration. If adding a section after first class meeting, contact your instructor as soon as you enroll.

subject: GRAD
title: Practicum for Future Faculty
info: Collegial support for teaching, faculty mentorship at regional college or university. Faculty role at various institutions. Classroom observation/feedback, preparation for academic job search.
prereqInfo: prereq: [8101 or equiv], [native English speaker or [ibTOEFL score of 27-30] or [ELP score of 1 from CTL]]

subject: GRAD
title: Teaching/Learning in Higher Ed
info: Create course materials for context/discipline. Assess student learning. Write action plan. Topics may include active learning in sciences, teaching with technology, multicultural education, teaching in clinical settings, learning-community course design.

subject: GRAD
title: Interdiscipl Diss Writing Sem
info: Led by graduate faculty. For course description, see sponsoring program(s).

subject: GRAD
title: DPD Seminar
info: This seminar is the culminating component of intensive work on dissertation proposal development. The program involves a five-day spring workshop, independent summer research, a five-day fall workshop, and opportunities for on-going interactions with the cohort and with faculty instructors. The work is designed to help participants develop cogent and fundable dissertation research proposals.
prereqInfo: The main goal of the spring workshop is to help clarify students research questions and scope as well as to better prepare them for a productive predissertation summer research experience.
